structured_info.title_cn: 将HOV车道转换为专用CACC车道对高速公路走廊交通流量的影响
structured_info.title_en: Traffic Flow Impacts of Converting an HOV Lane Into a Dedicated CACC Lane on a Freeway Corridor
structured_info.abstract: Cooperative Adaptive Cruise Control (CACC) systems can increase roadway capacity, but the benefits are marginal at low market penetration rates (MPRs). Thus, a CACC dedicated lane is considered to group CACC vehicles for efficient traffic stream. Concepts of converting existing High Occupancy Vehicle (HOV) lanes into CACC lanes emerge, which leverages the infrastructural facilities and experience with HOV lanes. However, it is unclear to which extent changing HOV lanes to CACC lanes can influence freeway operations. This study examines the traffic flow impacts of converting HOV lanes into CACC lanes regarding CACC MPRs on a complex freeway corridor with multiple interacting bottlenecks in California. A simulation model capable of reproducing flow characteristics with HOV lane and CACC systems is employed for the assessment. Special attention is paid to macroscopic congestion patterns, CACC lane utilization, travel time reliability and CACC operation characteristics. The results show that converting to CACC lanes at low MPRs ( ) can exacerbate congestion in general purpose lanes, whereas at mediate CACC MPRs (40 50 ) the congestion is drastically alleviated due to a large share of traffic carried by CACC lanes.
structured_info.methodology: Microscopic traffic simulation using an integrated car-following and lane change model for CACC and manually driven vehicles.
structured_info.conclusion: Converting an HOV lane to a CACC dedicated lane has different impacts depending on the market penetration rate of CACC vehicles. At low MPRs, it exacerbates congestion, while at medium MPRs (40-50%), congestion is alleviated due to higher CACC lane utilization.

analysis.Overview: The paper investigates the traffic flow impacts of converting High Occupancy Vehicle (HOV) lanes into dedicated Cooperative Adaptive Cruise Control (CACC) lanes on a freeway corridor, focusing on congestion patterns, travel time reliability, and CACC operation characteristics.
Background_and_Motivation: The research addresses the challenge of integrating CACC systems into existing traffic infrastructure to improve traffic flow efficiency.
The motivation stems from the marginal benefits of CACC at low market penetration rates (MPRs) and the potential of dedicated lanes to enhance CACC effectiveness.
The authors argue for the necessity of understanding the impacts of CACC lanes on traffic flow to guide infrastructure planning and policy.
The study relates the specific problem of CACC lane deployment to broader challenges in traffic management and autonomous vehicle integration.
The paper contributes to transportation engineering and intelligent transportation systems.
Conceptual_Framework_and_Innovations: Core concepts include CACC systems, HOV lanes, and traffic flow dynamics.
The logical relationship involves how CACC systems interact with traffic flow when deployed in dedicated lanes.
Key assumptions include the behavior of CACC vehicles and the impact of lane changes on traffic flow.
The paper contributes empirical insights into the effectiveness of CACC lanes at different MPRs.
Methodology: The study uses microscopic traffic simulation with integrated car-following and lane change models.
The methodology is novel in its detailed modeling of CACC vehicle behavior and lane change dynamics.
Data sources include loop detector data from a real freeway corridor in California.
Experimental design includes varying CACC MPRs and analyzing traffic flow metrics.
The research follows a simulation-based paradigm, common in traffic engineering.
Results: Key results show that CACC lanes at low MPRs worsen congestion, while at medium MPRs (40-50%), congestion is reduced.
Results are reliable and stable, supported by multiple simulation runs with different random seeds.
Argumentation_and_Logic: The argument structure involves presenting simulation results and analyzing their implications for traffic flow.
Key steps include model calibration, scenario simulation, and result analysis.
Strengths include detailed modeling; weaknesses include reliance on simulation without real-world validation.
Strengths_and_Limitations: Strengths include comprehensive simulation and detailed analysis of CACC lane impacts.
Limitations include the lack of real-world validation and assumptions about driver behavior.
Theoretical constraints include the focus on microscopic simulation, which may not capture all real-world complexities.
Academic_Discourse_and_Rhetoric: The paper contributes to ongoing discourse on autonomous vehicle integration into traffic systems.
Terminology is technical, targeting transportation engineering audiences.
Citations build authority by referencing prior work in CACC and traffic simulation.
Conclusions_and_Implications: Main conclusions highlight the need for sufficient CACC MPRs to justify dedicated lanes.
Future research should explore dynamic lane activation and mixed-use strategies for CACC lanes.
